title: Former Mayfair Home of Aviation Tycoon Sir Frederick Handley Page Asks £18.75M
text:
A flat on London's posh Grosvenor Square that was once the home of the British aviation tycoon Sir Frederick Handley Page hit the market Friday for £18.75 million (US$23.5 million).



A blue plaque on the facade of the neo-Georgian-style brick and stone apartment building commemorates Handley Page’s tenure in the third-floor apartment, where he lived from 1946 until his death in 1962.

It’s one of more than 900 blue plaques found on properties across London, all in place to remember a notable person that once lived inside.



Handley Page was famed for his aircraft manufacturing company, Handley Page Limited, and for designing bomber aircraft used by the British Royal Air Force during the two World Wars.



During his time in the Grosvenor Square apartment, his visitors included The Queen Mother—the late mother of Queen Elizabeth II—and tycoon Howard Hughes, according to a news release from listing brokerage Wetherell.



Now newly refurbished and modernized, the four-bedroom home has a marble entrance hall, bespoke doors, marble fireplaces, paneled walls and handcrafted European oak flooring, according to the release.



There’s also a study, a master bedroom suite with a walk-in dressing room, and one of the bedrooms is currently configured as a home cinema.

“This is an exceptional trophy property,” said Peter Wetherell, chief executive of Wetherell, in the release. It “would serve as an excellent long-term investment and main London residence.”

Grosvenor Square, in London’s affluent Mayfair neighborhood, has been one of the city’s most well-known super prime residential addresses since the 18th century, Mansion Global previously reported.



Recently, it’s been known more for diplomatic buildings than homes, but the square is in the midst of turning back to its luxury residential roots with the redevelopment and restoration of some of its most storied addresses, including the former U.S. embassy.



Mansion Global couldn’t determine the owner of the home.
